Award.AwardTitle: CSR: Medium: Collaborative Research: A Data-Centric Architecture for Pervasive Edge Computing in Heterogeneous Extensible Distributed Systems

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
The project aims to develop a novel data-centric architecture and accompanying protocols/algorithms to enable peer based data discovery, dissemination and processing for future mobile sensing applications among heterogeneous edge devices (e.g., smartphones, tablets) without relying on any centralized backend as is currently done.

The project uses named data to enable direct data sharing and processing among vast numbers of heterogeneous edge devices. The research systematically investigates: 1) Naming structures and constructs suitable for precise reference and characterization of various kinds of data; 2) Data discovery and name matching mechanisms for devices to find what data are available and acquire desired ones; 3) Transparent processing that derives and extracts new data from raw sensing samples. The project combines architecture, protocol and algorithm design, optimization, testbed implementations and software simulations for a full-scale study on the above issues.

This research will enable a future generation of mobile sensing applications no longer requiring a centralized backend, thus completely eliminating the associated monetary, manpower costs, and dependence on the availability and performance of Internet connectivity. The PIs are developing a new graduate course, training graduate students, and reaching out to undergraduate and high school students to build futuristic applications. Joint explorations with leading research and development organizations are conducted to apply the research results. The publications, software and experimental data are shared with the community to foster further research on this architecture.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Modern edge devices such as phones, tablets, Internet-of-Things (IOT), vehicles and drones are becoming increasingly pervasive and powerful. They can be equipped with diverse sensing hardware to generate multiple data streams, communication resources to share, exchange such data, and computing resources to process them. Future edge applications such as connected vehicles, smart homes will leverage such capabilities of edge devices.

However, today's applications are largely dependent on a cloud backend for functioning: devices usually upload all their data to the backend for processing, and receive instructions from the latter. This creates a fundamental mismatch for edge applications: the backend connections can be intermittent or non-existent; the latency or privacy leakage incurred can be intolerable.

This project has designed, developed and evaluated a novel data-centric architecture and accompanying protocols and algorithms to support a revolutionary "pervasive edge computing (PEC)" paradigm. It enables data collection, sharing and processing among peer edge devices, without involvement of the cloud backend. Thus future edge applications are no longer dependent on, and free from latency, privacy constraints from the cloud backend.

In this project, we have developed algorithms, protocols, and systems for: data centric naming structures and constructs for precise reference and characterization of various kinds of edge sensing data; peer based data discovery and sharing service for edge devices to find and retrieve data in the environment; a series of caching algorithms that handle different needs, including workload fairness among heterogeneous edge devices, continuously caching new data and driving out less valuable old data; two-layer structure of inter- and intra-group decisions under mobile scenarios; optimal incentive distribution to motivate relay nodes to move to suitable locations to bridge the gap in data exchange paths; data-centric wireless communication that provides high rate, low loss, one-to-many communication critically needed in many edge applications; blockchain systems for fair and efficient resource allocation among edge devices to enable fully decentralized data transactions, ensure profit sharing for data resale, and protect transactions from adverse modifications and denials; optimization of popular content caching in 5G edge network jointly with load balancing, routing and privacy protection; and pilot applications for vehicle navigation, real time human occupancy maps.

The project has produced more than twenty peer reviewed publications disseminated broadly in the research community. The data centric radio code has been released to the research community for prototyping edge applications, and potentially collaboration with the industry for piloting the radio is underway. The project has provided full or partial support and training for 6 Ph.D. students, 4 M.S. students (1 female), 19 undergraduate students (3 female), and 5 high school students (2 female).
